pyCoalesce.classes.entity_utilities module¶

@author: Scott Orr

These functions can be used to create and manipulate the XSD-based classes found in entity, coalesce_entity, and entity_template.

The parse functions were originally auto-generated by generateDS, and moved from the coalesce_entity module to this one.

Some of the functions don’t work properly with iPython’s auto-reload feature. In most cases, these problems can be overcome by restarting the kernel and reimporting everything at once, though even this workaround may not solve the problem in a few cases.

All functions can be imported directly from the pyCoalesce.classes module.

pyCoalesce.classes.entity_utilities.parsexml_(infile, parser=None, **kwargs)¶
pyCoalesce.classes.entity_utilities.get_root_tag(node)¶
pyCoalesce.classes.entity_utilities.parse(inFilename, object_class=None, silence=False)¶
pyCoalesce.classes.entity_utilities.parseEtree(inFilename, object_class=None, silence=False)¶
pyCoalesce.classes.entity_utilities.parseString(inString, object_class=None, silence=False)¶

Parse an XML string, create the object tree, and export it as a Coalesce object.

Parameters:
  • inString – a string. This XML fragment should not start with an XML declaration containing an encoding.
  • object_class – a subclass of any of the classes in pyCoalesce.classes.entity, or their subclasses in pyCoalesce.classes.coalesce_entity. This argument allows the instantiation of a subclass besides the ones in the latter module.
  • silence – a boolean. If False, export the object to stdout.
Returns:

the root object in the tree
pyCoalesce.classes.entity_utilities.parseLiteral(inFilename, object_class=None, silence=False)¶
pyCoalesce.classes.entity_utilities.to_XML_string(Coalesce_object, indent_level=1, pretty_print=True)¶

Assigns the XML representation of a Coalesce object to a string.

Parameters:
  • Coalesce_object – a Coalesce object with an “export” method
  • level – multiply by 4 to determine the number of spaces for each level of indentation
  • pretty_print – if True, add indentation
Returns:

a Unicode XML string
pyCoalesce.classes.entity_utilities.find_child(Coalesce_object, name, match_case=False, include_fielddefinitions=False)¶
Recursively searches a Coalesce object tree to find any objects
matching “name”.
Parameters:
  • Coalesce_object – a Coalesce object whose tree is to be searched
  • name – the (ASCII or Unicode) name of the object being searched for.
  • match_case – if True, match the case of “name”.
  • include_fielddefinitions – if True, include field definitions in the results. Normally, we want to exclude these, because they have the same names as fields, leading to ambiguity when using this function to find fields to set.
Returns:

a nested list containing paths to all matching objects. If “Coalesce_object” itself matches “name”, its “path” will be a list whose single item is “<root>”.

The function does not search linkages–these can always be found in the same place.

pyCoalesce.classes.entity_utilities.get_child_attrib(Coalesce_object, path=[u'<root>'], attrib='value')¶

Retrieves the value of one attribute of a child Coalesce object specified by “path”.

Parameters:
  • Coalesce_object – the root Coalesce object
  • path – a list of object types and indices that specifies the path to the child object whose attribute is to be retrieved. If the first (and presumably only) item in this argument is “<root>”, retrieve the attribute from “Coalesce_object” itself.
  • attrib – the name of the attribute to be retrieved. Defaults to “value”.
Returns:

the value of the target attribute
pyCoalesce.classes.entity_utilities.set_child_attrib(Coalesce_object, path=[u'<root>'], attrib='value', value=None)¶

Sets the value of one attribute of a child Coalesce object specified by “path”.

Parameters:
  • Coalesce_object – the root Coalesce object
  • path – a list of object types and indices that specifies the path to the child object whose attribute is to be set. If the first (and presumably only) item in this argument is “<root>”, set the attribute on the “Coalesce_object” itself.
  • attrib – the name of the attribute to be retrieved. Defaults to “value”. If the attribute does not already exist, it will be created.
  • value – the value to which the attribute is to be set
Returns:

True, indicating the attribute has been set successfully
pyCoalesce.classes.entity_utilities.set_entity_fields(Coalesce_entity=None, fields=None, match_case=False)¶

A convenience function to fill any or all of an entity’s :class:’fields <.pyCoalesce.classes.coalesce_entity.CoalesceField>’ with specified values.

Parameters:
  • Coalesce_entity – an instance of CoalesceEntity or one of its subclasses.
  • fields – a dict-like of fields and values to set on those fields. The keys can be either string (ASCII or Unicode) names (in which case the function searches for each field, and throws an error if duplicates are found) or path lists, alternating between child object type and list index. The values of the dict-like must be the values to be set on the value attribute of each field–use another method for setting other attributes.
  • match_case – if True, match the case of child object names in “fields”. This argument has no meaning if the keys of “fields” are paths.
Returns:

True if all fields have been set successfully

Technically, the function will work for any child object of a Coalesce entity (or the entity itself) that has an attribute named “value”, but this is unlikely to be the case for any actual Coalesce entity.
